I can understand using moments like midnight and January 1st as coordinators, so cultures and computers can agree on how to reference time. But shouldnâ€™t our personal markers and celebrations happen at personally meaningful times?

One approach to music is to do whatever you want. Absolutely anything goes. But to me, thatâ€™s too free. Itâ€™s anti-inspiring because having infinite options is overwhelming.

Another approach to music is to follow tradition. You stay within the guidelines of a genre or style. But to me, thatâ€™s too strict and sad. It was someone elseâ€™s innovation. To imitate it now with rules and recipes is just nostalgia. Itâ€™s uninspired and dishonest.

So my favorite approach to music is in-between. You make up your own rules, and apply them to a piece of music. You know what this is called? An experiment!

  • Experiment with limitations. Write a piece using only two instruments and five notes. Write a lyric using only nouns and no verbs.
  • Experiment with textures. Record an arrangement using only childrenâ€™s toys or samples of birds.
  • Experiment with density. Write a piece featuring fifty instruments. Then do a solo piece using only your left hand.

I loved learning and applying specific techniques. Like Iâ€™d learn a certain way of developing a melody, then go write melodies using that method. Iâ€™d learn about re-harmonizing â€” where you keep the same melody but change the chords underneath, completely changing the mood â€” then Iâ€™d go apply that to all of my songs. Techniques to build tension. Techniques to change time.

With each new thing I learn, I have to try it, and make something. It might not even sound good, but thatâ€™s OK. The goal was just to see what happens, so thereâ€™s no way to fail. Itâ€™s all just fertilizer for future creations.

â€¦

Iâ€™m not an active musician anymore, but now I find that the way I approached music is the way I approach life.

After I sold my company and life was a blank slate, I found that having too much freedom was overwhelming.

But Iâ€™m not going to buy into an -ism and follow a set of ancient rules.

So instead I do experiments. I make up rules, and apply them to my life for a while. Likeâ€¦

  • Experiment with limitations, fear, detachment, or my definition of home.
  • Experiment with fame, boundaries, expanding, quitting, or my self-image.
  • Experiment with vulnerability, commitment, saying yes, or saying no.

I usually try the opposite of whatever I did before.

I still love learning and applying specific techniques. Techniques for conversation. Techniques to stretch time. Iâ€™m glad I know how to re-harmonize because there are melodies in my past I canâ€™t change, but I can change the thoughts underneath.

With each new thing I learn, I have to try it. It might not even feel good, but thatâ€™s what experimenting is about. The goal is still to see what happens, so thereâ€™s no way to fail.

I donâ€™t usually talk about money, but a friend asked me what it was like to get rich, and he wanted to know specifics, so I told him my story.

I had a day job in midtown Manhattan paying $20K per year â€” about minimum wage. On weekends I would earn $150 per day performing circus shows for kids, though Iâ€™d spend about $50 in bus fare to get to the gigs. I was sharing a three-bedroom apartment with two other roommates in Queens, so our rent was $333 per month each. I made peanut butter sandwiches for three meals a day, and at night maybe some eggs. I never ate out, and never took a taxi. My cost of living was about $1000/month, and I was earning $1800/month. I did this for two years, and saved up $12,000. I was 22 years old.

Once I had $12,000 I could quit my job and become a full-time musician. I knew I could get a few gigs per month to pay my cost of living. So I was free. I quit my job a month later, and never had a job again.

When I finished telling my friend this story, he asked for more. I said no, that was it. He said, â€œNo, what about when you sold your company?â€

I said no, that didnâ€™t make a big difference in my life. That was just more money in the bank. The difference happened when I was 22.

Itâ€™s not how much you have. Itâ€™s the difference between what you have and what you spend. If you have more than you spend, youâ€™re rich. If you spend more than you have, youâ€™re not. If you live cheaply, itâ€™s easy to be free.

Magicians wave one hand around to get your attention, while the other hand does the trick. To be smart, watch the other hand.

If youâ€™re in doubt about something thatâ€™s not in your life, try it. Things are so different in practice versus in theory. The only way to know is to experience it yourself.

  • Pursuing a new interest?
  • Moving somewhere very different?
  • Quitting your job to go freelance?

Err on the side of yes. Try it. If it was a mistake, at least youâ€™ll know first-hand, instead of always wondering.

If youâ€™re in doubt about something thatâ€™s in your life already, get rid of it. Not just things, this goes for identities, habits, goals, relationships, technology, and anything else. Default to not having it, then see how you do without.

Get rid of it examples:

  • Relationships that bring you down
  • Goals youâ€™re not pursuing
  • A career thatâ€™s plateaued

Err on the side of no. Get rid of it. Start with a clean slate, If it was a mistake, youâ€™ll get it back with a renewed enthusiasm.

(The common thread is to make the change, to know first-hand.)

Get rid of everything examples:

  • Erase your phone and computer. Re-install the operating system from scratch. Donâ€™t restore from the backup â€” not even your contacts. Only add back people who contact you. Donâ€™t install any apps unless you canâ€™t do without them.
  • Put everything you own into storage. Move somewhere small and simple, bringing only what youâ€™d take on a two-week trip. Only when you absolutely need something, go get it out of storage. After a year, sell all that stuff in storage.

entry.content:
When someone becomes an expert at something, you know what else they become? Annoying.

At a restaurant, your designer friend complains about the font on the menu, your musician friend complains about the background music, and your manager friend complains about the service. Why?

The problem is that their expertise makes them annoyed. Theyâ€™re trained to spot errors. Theyâ€™re so aware of whatâ€™s wrong. Even worse, they know exactly how to fix it. They learned the techniques to make things great, so theyâ€™re angry when someone didnâ€™t do the obvious solution. They get so frustrated that they canâ€™t focus on their meal, because now they really want to fix the problem.

These things donâ€™t bother the rest of us. Weâ€™re easier to please. Good is good enough.

So only those who are the most upset, and know how to improve things, do the hard work necessary to make things great. The dissatisfied ones go make things better for all of us.

Why are experts annoying? For our benefit. They get mad so that we donâ€™t have to.

Next time your friend is upset and ranting about design, politics, layout, economics, or something else you donâ€™t care enough about, thank them for taking on the burden of knowing how to fix things, and remind them that itâ€™s up to them to make it better.

People up north are so serious, I felt like a lightweight clown.

People down south are so laid-back, I had to escape north again.

The way we define ourself is all relative to our surroundings, right? However we differ from the people in our home town is how we define ourself. Thatâ€™s where we shape our self-identity, growing up. Those are our defining traits.

But when we go to a different place, the relative comparisons collapse. Traits like speed, ambition, independence, bravery, and humor â€” theyâ€™re all relative.

Back home Iâ€™m considered quiet. Here Iâ€™m considered loud.

Back home Iâ€™m a slacker. Here Iâ€™m a workaholic.

Back home Iâ€™m normal. Here Iâ€™m strange. Or vice-versa. So how do I define myself now?

I always want to know why a culture is this way. Whatâ€™s the difference? What are the core beliefs? So I ask questions and observe.

On the surface and from a distance, I see their actions. But deeply and closely, I see my reactions.

You couldnâ€™t just roll down the street leaving huge piles of garbage everywhere you go, making life slower for everyone as they climb over your mountains of junk, just to get on with their life. Youâ€™d feel bad about it, right?

Thatâ€™s how I feel about the digital things we put out into the world: websites, apps, and files.

<svg height="54" width="54">
<defs><style type="text/css"><![CDATA[line,polygon{stroke:black;stroke-width:4} polygon{fill:black}]]></style></defs>

Much better! 95% smaller file size, and the joy of making something by hand instead of having it done for me.
